Karl,

I wanted to follow on a bit on what Colin said.  I agree Colin's 
method might help but I want to just point out what might be going 
on.  You seem to have run into a classic local optimum.  It's 
probably a situation where it's very easy to get some of the 
classifications right using some rough heuristic which is found 
early on, but then to get any of the other classifications right 
requires *sacrificing* the naive function that was found first, 
which is almost never going to happen since it means dropping in 
fitness for a while.  The presence of species should help with this 
problem but the basin around the initial poor solution may be so 
large that it's virtually inevitable to get pulled in.

This kind of thing seems to happen more in classification problems 
than control problems (just based on my observations, not 
experimental backup).  I'd try Colin's suggestions but if that 
doesn't work then probably the fitness function needs some tuning,
perhaps extreme ad hoc tuning based on what you know is happening.  
In other words, which examples does it tend to get right when its 
stuck?  Maybe you can do something to avoid awarding that situation.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "blackkm7" <karl.black@h...> wrote:
> Colin,
> Thanks for the write-up... interesting ideas!
> 
> Do you know if anyone has added "phasing" or de-complexification 
> mutation code to JNEAT? and is it available?  I'd like to try it 
with 
> the digital output experiment.
> 
> Karl
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> > Hi Karl,
> > 
> > Your diagram looks OK here BTW :)
> > 
> > The problem domain you describe is very similar to the Simple-
OCR

> used in 
> > my recent phased search write-up. I also observed poor results, 
> although 
> > the OCR domain has a lot more input and output nodes than your 
> digital 
> > display domain.
> > 
> > Anyway, I raised a number of issues in the write-up which I 
can't 
> really 
> > do justice here so I would recommend you have a read and see 
what 
> you 
> > think. From my experiments with Simple-OCR and knowing that your 
> digital 
> > display domain problem has far fewer inputs and ouptuts, I am 
> fairly 
> > confident that this could be solved in SharpNEAT in it's current 
> state. 
> > I am willing to implement it and make another release if there 
are 
> any 
> > doubters :)
> > 
> > Oh the URL for the write-up is 
> www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com/phasedsearch.htm
> > 
> > Colin.
